dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so for investors, um, what's happening with battery metal miners right now really feels like a rerun of, like, 2017, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so for investors, um, what's happening with battery metal miners right now really feels like a rerun of, like, twenty seventeen, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For investors. whats happening with battery-metal miners looks like a re-run of the boom conditions in 2017 when share prices rocketed up despite sluggish EV sales.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I know exactly what you mean. That first boom back then, uh, it ended in a pretty spectacular bust because EV sales just weren't there to meet the metal supply. Classic "arriving too early to the party," right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I know exactly what you mean. That first boom back then, uh, it ended in a pretty spectacular bust because E V sales just weren't there to meet the metal supply. Classic arriving too early to the party, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That first flush of demand for mining and exploration companies exposed to lithium, graphite, cobalt and nickel ended in a spectacular bust because metal supply significantly outstripped demand for EVs. The battery metals crash, which lasted until early this year, was a classic demonstration of arriving too early at a partywhich can be worse than being last to leave.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But this time, it *should* be different, right? Because EV demand actually *is* rising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But this time, it should be different, right? Because E V demand actually is rising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I mean, look at Tesla's sales last year â€“ up 36% despite, you know, everything with COVID. That's a huge indicator.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I mean, look at Tesla's sales last year - up thirty six percent despite, you know, everything with C O V I D. That's a huge indicator.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Tesla's still on top, but it's not just them anymore. We're seeing Mercedes, Toyota, Ford, Audi, um, all these traditional carmakers joining the race.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Tesla's still on top, but it's not just them anymore. We're seeing Mercedes, Toyota, Ford, Audi, um, all these traditional carmakers joining the race.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Tesla is the current EV leader, it is being joined in the race to overtake internal combustion engines by traditional vehicle leaders, such as Mercedes Benz, Toyota, Ford and Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just the carmakers, A. Government incentives are kicking in, and we're seeing obstacles like range anxiety and charging stations slowly being overcome.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just the carmakers, A. Government incentives are kicking in, and we're seeing obstacles like range anxiety and charging stations slowly being overcome.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Increasing competition for EV sales, as obstacles such as limited charging stations and range anxiety are overcome, is being boosted by government incentives for drivers to make the switch.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, speaking of, the whole shift accelerated after, uh, Biden was elected. Tesla's stock, like, shot up 76% since early November.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, speaking of, the whole shift accelerated after, uh, Biden was elected. Tesla's stock, like, shot up seventy six percent since early November.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two months since the U.S. elected a more environmentally focused President in Joe Biden, the shift towards EVs has accelerated and can be seen in Teslas 76% share price rise since early November from $400 a share to $705.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It did! But what's really fascinating is that the battery metal companies are actually matching, and in some cases, even *beating* that rise.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It did! But what's really fascinating is that the battery metal companies are actually matching, and in some cases, even beating that rise.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Teslas rise has been matched, and in some cases beaten, by battery metal companies as they are being re-discovered by investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally! Pilbara Minerals, a lithium producer, is up 137% since November. That's, um, crazy money in just a few weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally! Pilbara Minerals, a lithium producer, is up one hundred thirty seven percent since November. That's, um, crazy money in just a few weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pilbara Minerals, an Australian producer of lithium, is up 137% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] It's insane, even for a smaller company. And Albemarle too, up nearly 60%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's insane, even for a smaller company. And Albemarle too, up nearly sixty percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S.-based Albemarle Corporation has enjoyed a 58% share price rise since November 4, up from $93.43 on the New York Stock Exchange to $147.52 at the close on Friday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just lithium, right? Graphite explorers, like Talga Group, are also seeing, uh, huge gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just lithium, right? Graphite explorers, like Talga Group, are also seeing, uh, huge gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Graphite explorers and producers have shared in the return of confidence in the battery metals story with Talga Group, an Australian-based and Swedish-focused developer of graphite products, up 65% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's the whole sector getting rediscovered. And the big investment banks are dusting off their research, too. Goldman Sachs, for example, just lifted its lithium forecasts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's the whole sector getting rediscovered. And the big investment banks are dusting off their research, too. Goldman Sachs, for example, just lifted its lithium forecasts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investment banks have been dusting off their battery metal research. Goldman Sachs, late last month, lifted its forecasts for lithium.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. Spodumene and lithium hydroxide, um, they're expecting significant price increases this year and next.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. Spodumene and lithium hydroxide, um, they're expecting significant price increases this year and next.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spodumene (a primary ore of the metal) is tipped to rise from $395 a ton to $536/t this year. Lithium hydroxide (a processed form of the metal) is forecast to rise from $10,882/t to $11,800 and then up to $13,000/t in 2023.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which really points to the key difference this time: genuine, rapid growth in consumer demand for EVs. That was the missing link back in 2017.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which really points to the key difference this time: genuine, rapid growth in consumer demand for E V s. That was the missing link back in twenty seventeen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The key to the revitalization of the battery metals sector lies in rapid growth in consumer demand for EVs, the missing link in the original flush of enthusiasm...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Tesla's leading, but all these other vehicle makers are just compounding that demand. And that could potentially, um, lead to shortages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Tesla's leading, but all these other vehicle makers are just compounding that demand. And that could potentially, um, lead to shortages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and while it is Tesla leading the way, other vehicle makers are compounding demand growth and potentially exposing a shortage of some critical metals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Potentially, yeah. And if shortages do develop, we could see those battery metal prices spike even higher.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potentially, yeah. And if shortages do develop, we could see those battery metal prices spike even higher.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If shortages do develop, battery metal prices could spike higher with a corresponding effect on share prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, for investors in these miners, could mean even bigger returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, for investors in these miners, could mean even bigger returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If shortages do develop, battery metal prices could spike higher with a corresponding effect on share prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's definitely an exciting, uh, and volatile space to keep an eye on right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's definitely an exciting, uh, and volatile space to keep an eye on right now.
